title: Oma's Fabulous Matzo Ball Soup Recipe
description: This matzo ball soup recipe, made with homemade matzo balls cooked in simmering chicken broth, is quick and easy to make and a perfect Passover staple.

About Us The Allrecipes Allstars How to Add a Recipe GET THE MAGAZINE Recipes Holidays and Events Recipes Passover Oma's Fabulous Matzo Ball Soup 4.2 (89) 70 Reviews 11 Photos This matzo ball soup recipe is the one my grandmother always made. The matzo balls are perfect! It is our family's favorite Passover dish and serves a lot of people. Make sure to not add too much matzo meal in order to make the matzo balls float to the top of the boiling chicken broth. Submitted by May Gerstle Updated on April 8, 2025 Save Rate Print Share Close Add Photo 11 11 11 11 Prep Time: 30 mins Cook Time: 25 mins Total Time: 55 mins Servings: 10 Jump to Nutrition Facts Cook Mode (Keep screen awake) Ingredients 1x 2x 4x Oops! Something went wrong. Our team is working on it. Original recipe (1X) yields 10 servings 2 (10-ounce) packages matzo crackers ½ cup oil or butter (See Cook's Note.) 6 large eggs, or more if needed, beaten 2 onions, minced 3 tablespoons minced fresh parsley salt and ground black pepper to taste 5 ounces matzo meal 3 (32-ounce) cartons chicken broth Directions Gather the ingredients. Bring a large pot of lightly salted water to a boil. Morgan Hunt Glaze / Food Stylist: Emily Nabors Hall / Prop Stylist: Hannah Greenwood Meanwhile, break matzo crackers into small pieces; place in a large bowl. Add tap water to cover; allow to soak until soft, a few minutes. Drain off excess water. Morgan Hunt Glaze / Food Stylist: Emily Nabors Hall / Prop Stylist: Hannah Greenwood Heat oil in a large skillet over medium heat. Add drained matzo crackers; stir until dry and slightly brown. Remove from heat; stir in eggs, onion, parsley, salt, and pepper. Stir in just enough matzo meal until mixture holds together. Morgan Hunt Glaze / Food Stylist: Emily Nabors Hall / Prop Stylist: Hannah Greenwood Roll mixture into one 2-inch matzo ball; place in the boiling water to test consistency. The ball must rise to the top of the water and not break apart. If it doesn't rise, too much matzo meal was added; add another beaten egg to the mixture and test again. When desired consistency is reached, roll mixture into 2-inch balls. Morgan Hunt Glaze / Food Stylist: Emily Nabors Hall / Prop Stylist: Hannah Greenwood Bring chicken broth in a large saucepan to a lively simmer over medium heat. Carefully add matzo balls; simmer until balls are cooked through and rise to the top of the broth. Serve. Morgan Hunt Glaze / Food Stylist: Emily Nabors Hall / Prop Stylist: Hannah Greenwood Cook’s Note To make this recipe kosher, use vegetable oil or butter-flavored shortening that's non-dairy. I Made It Print 121 home cooks made it! Your daily values may be higher or lower depending on your calorie needs. ** Nutrient information is not available for all ingredients. Amount is based on available nutrient data. Add Your Photo Photos of Oma's Fabulous Matzo Ball Soup 01 of 11 Photo by  Morgan Hunt Glaze / Food Stylist: Emily Nabors Hall / Prop Stylist: Hannah Greenwood 02 of 11 Photo by  Sujo Robert 04/25/2019 I used thyme instead of parsley this year. It has a nice flavour. My daughter loves it. 03 of 11 Photo by  Liz Dalton 'Lizzie' 08/31/2016 I subbed vegetable oil for the butter and fork whipped the eggs before adding. Delicious! I will be making again and again. 04 of 11 Photo by  Jarryd Stewart 04/15/2014 05 of 11 Photo by  Jarryd Stewart 04/15/2014 06 of 11 Photo by  Deanna Peshl 04/15/2014 First time ever making matzo ball soup and let me tell you...not only was it fantastic but it was easy too! Made it for Passover and it was a hit! The matzo ball recipe makes a lot! I froze the extra in rolled balls. 07 of 11 Photo by  Jess Lew 04/02/2014 Best matzoh ball soup I have ever had! (I have been eating this "homemade" [made with matzoh meal] my entire life). I loved that real matzoh was used for the batter rather than skipping the steps and using prepared matzoh meal; these matzoh balls have a much richer flavor and subtle, yet interesting texture than those made entirely with the prepared meal. To keep kosher - use shmaltz (chicken skin renderings) and vegetable based oil of choice instead of butter. Do not continuously add more matzoh meal if the batter does not stick together;instead, make sure to alternately add meal and eggs until the batter is a soft, doughy texture, similar to meatballs. Add a few carrots, celery, and onions chopped in inch-long pieces and fry them with canola oil and parsley and dump them into same soup base. Use this same pan to fry the rehydrated matzoh in to use the most of this freshly flavored oil left in the pan. Also, make sure to flour your hand continuously while forming the matzoh balls to avoid having the batter stuck to your hands; this will enable you to form the balls in your hands through rolling rather than relying on the stickiness of the matzoh meal and eggs alone. Happy cooking! :) 08 of 11 Photo by  sanzoe 04/20/2009 09 of 11 Photo by  megnrn 03/03/2008 Very good. Makes lots of balls. I froze more than half of them. I thought I had my mixture wrong, because the balls did not float right away. Give them a few minutes, they floated for me. 10 of 11 Photo by  megnrn 03/03/2008 Very good. Makes lots of balls. I froze more than half of them. I thought I had my mixture wrong, because the balls did not float right away. Give them a few minutes, they floated for me. 1 2 Next You’ll Also Love Angel Family Chicken Soup with Matzo Balls 14 Ratings Passover Soup with Chicken Dumplings 4 Ratings 11 Delicious Ways to Use Leftover Matzo What Is a Matzo Ball?
